validation_note: The interaction and its pathological function are well-supported by recent literature. The input data accurately reflects that mislocalized cytoplasmic NUP62 directly interacts with TDP-43, promoting its aggregation and insolubility in ALS/FTD.

functions.cellular_process: In pathological conditions like ALS/FTD, the nuclear pore protein NUP62 is depleted from the nucleus and mislocalizes to the cytoplasm. There, it directly interacts with cytoplasmic TDP-43.
functions.effect_description: This interaction promotes the liquid-to-solid phase transition of TDP-43, accelerating its conversion into insoluble, pathological aggregates. Cytoplasmic NUP62 acts as a scaffold, and its interaction with TDP-43 promotes the insolubility of both proteins.
biological_consequence: Promotion of TDP-43 liquid-to-solid phase transition
specific_effects: Cytoplasmic NUP62 co-localizes with phosphorylated TDP-43 in cytoplasmic inclusions in C9orf72 and sporadic ALS/FTD patient tissues.
The interaction between cytoplasmic NUP62 and TDP-43 promotes the insolubility of both proteins.
Pathological TDP-43 can trigger the cytoplasmic sequestration of NUP62.
The interaction is dependent on the Nuclear Localization Signal (NLS) of TDP-43.

evidence.paper_title: NUP62 localizes to ALS/FTLD pathological assemblies and contributes to TDP-43 insolubility
evidence.relevant_quote: Cytoplasmic NUP62 and TDP-43 interactions promotes their insolubility and NUP62:TDP-43 inclusions are frequently found in C9orf72 ALS/FTLD as well as sporadic ALS/FTLD postmortem CNS tissue. Our findings indicate NUP62 cytoplasmic mislocalization contributes to TDP-43 proteinopathy in ALS/FTLD.
evidence.authors: Gleixner AM, Verdone BM, Otte CG, Anderson EN, Ramesh N, Shapiro OR, Gale JR, Mauna JC, Mann JR, Copley KE, Daley EL, Ortega JA, Cicardi ME, Kiskinis E, Kofler J, Pandey UB, Trotti D, Donnelly CJ

evidence.paper_title: Mislocalization of Nup62 Contributes to TDP-43 Proteinopathy in ALS/FTLD
evidence.relevant_quote: The mislocalized Nup62 was colocalized with TDP-43 in cytoplasmic inclusions and promoted its liquid-to-solid transition. The work highlights the involvement of Nup62 in the pathogenesis of ALS/FTLD and the interaction between Nup62 and TDP-43.

evidence.paper_title: TDP-43 pathology disrupts nuclear pore complexes and nucleocytoplasmic transport in ALS/FTD
evidence.relevant_quote: Here we used proximity-dependent biotin identification (BioID) to interrogate the interactome of detergent-insoluble TDP-43 aggregates and found them enriched for components of the nuclear pore complex and nucleocytoplasmic transport machinery.
evidence.authors: Chou CC, Zhang Y, Umoh ME, Vaughan SW, Lorenzini I, Liu F, Sayegh M, Donlin-Asp PG, Chen YH, Duong DM, Seyfried NT, Powers MA, Kukar T, Hales CM, Gearing M, Cairns NJ, Boylan KB, Dickson DW, Rademakers R, Zhang YJ, Petrucelli L, Cook C, Gendron TF

mechanism: In pathological conditions like ALS/FTD, the nuclear pore protein NUP62 is depleted from the nucleus and mislocalizes to the cytoplasm. There, it directly interacts with cytoplasmic TDP-43.
effect: This interaction promotes the liquid-to-solid phase transition of TDP-43, accelerating its conversion into insoluble, pathological aggregates. Cytoplasmic NUP62 acts as a scaffold, and its interaction with TDP-43 promotes the insolubility of both proteins.
summary: TDP43 activates NUP62 to modulate tdp-43 cytoplasmic aggregation.

Our findings indicate NUP62 cytoplasmic mislocalization contributes to TDP-43 proteinopathy in ALS/FTLD.
